speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: SCENE III. A lonely part of the forest.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Enter AARON, with a bag of gold

speaker: AARON
text_entry: He that had wit would think that I had none,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: To bury so much gold under a tree,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And never after to inherit it.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Let him that thinks of me so abjectly

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Know that this gold must coin a stratagem,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Which, cunningly effected, will beget

speaker: AARON
text_entry: A very excellent piece of villany:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And so repose, sweet gold, for their unrest

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Hides the gold

speaker: AARON
text_entry: That have their alms out of the empress' chest.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Enter TAMORA

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: My lovely Aaron, wherefore look'st thou sad,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: When every thing doth make a gleeful boast?

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: The birds chant melody on every bush,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: The snake lies rolled in the cheerful sun,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: The green leaves quiver with the cooling wind

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And make a chequer'd shadow on the ground:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Under their sweet shade, Aaron, let us sit,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And, whilst the babbling echo mocks the hounds,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Replying shrilly to the well-tuned horns,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: As if a double hunt were heard at once,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Let us sit down and mark their yelping noise;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And, after conflict such as was supposed

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: The wandering prince and Dido once enjoy'd,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: When with a happy storm they were surprised

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And curtain'd with a counsel-keeping cave,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: We may, each wreathed in the other's arms,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Our pastimes done, possess a golden slumber;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Whiles hounds and horns and sweet melodious birds

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Be unto us as is a nurse's song

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Of lullaby to bring her babe asleep.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Madam, though Venus govern your desires,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Saturn is dominator over mine:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: What signifies my deadly-standing eye,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: My silence and my cloudy melancholy,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: My fleece of woolly hair that now uncurls

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Even as an adder when she doth unroll

speaker: AARON
text_entry: To do some fatal execution?

speaker: AARON
text_entry: No, madam, these are no venereal signs:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Vengeance is in my heart, death in my hand,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Blood and revenge are hammering in my head.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Hark Tamora, the empress of my soul,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Which never hopes more heaven than rests in thee,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: This is the day of doom for Bassianus:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: His Philomel must lose her tongue to-day,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Thy sons make pillage of her chastity

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And wash their hands in Bassianus' blood.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Seest thou this letter? take it up, I pray thee,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And give the king this fatal plotted scroll.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Now question me no more; we are espied;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Here comes a parcel of our hopeful booty,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Which dreads not yet their lives' destruction.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Ah, my sweet Moor, sweeter to me than life!

speaker: AARON
text_entry: No more, great empress; Bassianus comes:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Be cross with him; and I'll go fetch thy sons

speaker: AARON
text_entry: To back thy quarrels, whatsoe'er they be.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Exit

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Enter BASSIANUS and LAVINIA

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Who have we here? Rome's royal empress,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Unfurnish'd of her well-beseeming troop?

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Or is it Dian, habited like her,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Who hath abandoned her holy groves

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: To see the general hunting in this forest?

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Saucy controller of our private steps!

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Had I the power that some say Dian had,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Thy temples should be planted presently

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: With horns, as was Actaeon's; and the hounds

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Should drive upon thy new-transformed limbs,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Unmannerly intruder as thou art!

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Under your patience, gentle empress,

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: 'Tis thought you have a goodly gift in horning;

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: And to be doubted that your Moor and you

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Are singled forth to try experiments:

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Jove shield your husband from his hounds to-day!

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: 'Tis pity they should take him for a stag.

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Believe me, queen, your swarth Cimmerian

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Doth make your honour of his body's hue,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Spotted, detested, and abominable.

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Why are you sequester'd from all your train,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Dismounted from your snow-white goodly steed.

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: And wander'd hither to an obscure plot,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Accompanied but with a barbarous Moor,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: If foul desire had not conducted you?

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: And, being intercepted in your sport,

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Great reason that my noble lord be rated

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: For sauciness. I pray you, let us hence,

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: And let her joy her raven-colour'd love;

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: This valley fits the purpose passing well.

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: The king my brother shall have note of this.

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Ay, for these slips have made him noted long:

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Good king, to be so mightily abused!

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Why have I patience to endure all this?

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Enter DEMETRIUS and CHIRON

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: How now, dear sovereign, and our gracious mother!

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Why doth your highness look so pale and wan?

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Have I not reason, think you, to look pale?

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: These two have 'ticed me hither to this place:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: A barren detested vale, you see it is;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: The trees, though summer, yet forlorn and lean,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: O'ercome with moss and baleful mistletoe:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Here never shines the sun; here nothing breeds,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Unless the nightly owl or fatal raven:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And when they show'd me this abhorred pit,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: They told me, here, at dead time of the night,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: A thousand fiends, a thousand hissing snakes,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Ten thousand swelling toads, as many urchins,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Would make such fearful and confused cries

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: As any mortal body hearing it

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Should straight fall mad, or else die suddenly.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: No sooner had they told this hellish tale,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: But straight they told me they would bind me here

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Unto the body of a dismal yew,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And leave me to this miserable death:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And then they call'd me foul adulteress,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Lascivious Goth, and all the bitterest terms

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: That ever ear did hear to such effect:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And, had you not by wondrous fortune come,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: This vengeance on me had they executed.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Revenge it, as you love your mother's life,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Or be ye not henceforth call'd my children.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: This is a witness that I am thy son.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Stabs BASSIANUS

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: And this for me, struck home to show my strength.

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: Also stabs BASSIANUS, who dies

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Ay, come, Semiramis, nay, barbarous Tamora,

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: For no name fits thy nature but thy own!

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Give me thy poniard; you shall know, my boys

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Your mother's hand shall right your mother's wrong.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Stay, madam; here is more belongs to her;

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: First thrash the corn, then after burn the straw:

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: This minion stood upon her chastity,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Upon her nuptial vow, her loyalty,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: And with that painted hope braves your mightiness:

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: And shall she carry this unto her grave?

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: An if she do, I would I were an eunuch.

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: Drag hence her husband to some secret hole,

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: And make his dead trunk pillow to our lust.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: But when ye have the honey ye desire,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Let not this wasp outlive, us both to sting.

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: I warrant you, madam, we wil l make that sure.

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: Come, mistress, now perforce we will enjoy

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: That nice-preserved honesty of yours.

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: O Tamora! thou bear'st a woman's face,--

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: I will not hear her speak; away with her!

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Sweet lords, entreat her hear me but a word.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Listen, fair madam: let it be your glory

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: To see her tears; but be your heart to them

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: As unrelenting flint to drops of rain.

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: When did the tiger's young ones teach the dam?

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: O, do not learn her wrath; she taught it thee;

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: The milk thou suck'dst from her did turn to marble;

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Even at thy teat thou hadst thy tyranny.

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Yet every mother breeds not sons alike:

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: To CHIRON

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Do thou entreat her show a woman pity.

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: What, wouldst thou have me prove myself a bastard?

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: 'Tis true; the raven doth not hatch a lark:

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Yet have I heard,--O, could I find it now!--

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: The lion moved with pity did endure

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: To have his princely paws pared all away:

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Some say that ravens foster forlorn children,

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: The whilst their own birds famish in their nests:

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: O, be to me, though thy hard heart say no,

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Nothing so kind, but something pitiful!

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: I know not what it means; away with her!

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: O, let me teach thee! for my father's sake,

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: That gave thee life, when well he might have

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: slain thee,

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Be not obdurate, open thy deaf ears.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Hadst thou in person ne'er offended me,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Even for his sake am I pitiless.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Remember, boys, I pour'd forth tears in vain,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: To save your brother from the sacrifice;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: But fierce Andronicus would not relent;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Therefore, away with her, and use her as you will,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: The worse to her, the better loved of me.

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: O Tamora, be call'd a gentle queen,

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: And with thine own hands kill me in this place!

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: For 'tis not life that I have begg'd so long;

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Poor I was slain when Bassianus died.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: What begg'st thou, then? fond woman, let me go.

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: 'Tis present death I beg; and one thing more

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: That womanhood denies my tongue to tell:

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: O, keep me from their worse than killing lust,

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: And tumble me into some loathsome pit,

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Where never man's eye may behold my body:

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Do this, and be a charitable murderer.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: So should I rob my sweet sons of their fee:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: No, let them satisfy their lust on thee.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Away! for thou hast stay'd us here too long.

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: No grace? no womanhood? Ah, beastly creature!

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: The blot and enemy to our general name!

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Confusion fall--

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: Nay, then I'll stop your mouth. Bring thou her husband:

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: This is the hole where Aaron bid us hide him.

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: DEMETRIUS throws the body of BASSIANUS into the  pit; then exeunt DEMETRIUS and CHIRON, dragging off LAVINIA

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Farewell, my sons: see that you make her sure.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Ne'er let my heart know merry cheer indeed,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Till all the Andronici be made away.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Now will I hence to seek my lovely Moor,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And let my spleenful sons this trull deflow'r.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Re-enter AARON, with QUINTUS and MARTIUS

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Come on, my lords, the better foot before:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Straight will I bring you to the loathsome pit

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Where I espied the panther fast asleep.

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: My sight is very dull, whate'er it bodes.

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: And mine, I promise you; were't not for shame,

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: Well could I leave our sport to sleep awhile.

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: Falls into the pit

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: What art thou fall'n? What subtle hole is this,

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: Whose mouth is cover'd with rude-growing briers,

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: Upon whose leaves are drops of new-shed blood

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: As fresh as morning dew distill'd on flowers?

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: A very fatal place it seems to me.

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: Speak, brother, hast thou hurt thee with the fall?

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: O brother, with the dismall'st object hurt

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: That ever eye with sight made heart lament!

speaker: AARON
text_entry: [Aside]  Now will I fetch the king to find them here,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: That he thereby may give a likely guess

speaker: AARON
text_entry: How these were they that made away his brother.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Exit

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: Why dost not comfort me, and help me out

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: From this unhallowed and blood-stained hole?

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: I am surprised with an uncouth fear;

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: A chilling sweat o'er-runs my trembling joints:

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: My heart suspects more than mine eye can see.

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: To prove thou hast a true-divining heart,

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: Aaron and thou look down into this den,

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: And see a fearful sight of blood and death.

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: Aaron is gone; and my compassionate heart

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: Will not permit mine eyes once to behold

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: The thing whereat it trembles by surmise;

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: O, tell me how it is; for ne'er till now

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: Was I a child to fear I know not what.

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: Lord Bassianus lies embrewed here,

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: All on a heap, like to a slaughter'd lamb,

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: In this detested, dark, blood-drinking pit.

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: If it be dark, how dost thou know 'tis he?

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: Upon his bloody finger he doth wear

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: A precious ring, that lightens all the hole,

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: Which, like a taper in some monument,

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: Doth shine upon the dead man's earthy cheeks,

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: And shows the ragged entrails of the pit:

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: So pale did shine the moon on Pyramus

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: When he by night lay bathed in maiden blood.

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: O brother, help me with thy fainting hand--

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: If fear hath made thee faint, as me it hath--

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: Out of this fell devouring receptacle,

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: As hateful as Cocytus' misty mouth.

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: Reach me thy hand, that I may help thee out;

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: Or, wanting strength to do thee so much good,

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: I may be pluck'd into the swallowing womb

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: Of this deep pit, poor Bassianus' grave.

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: I have no strength to pluck thee to the brink.

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: Nor I no strength to climb without thy help.

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: Thy hand once more; I will not loose again,

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: Till thou art here aloft, or I below:

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: Thou canst not come to me: I come to thee.

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: Falls in

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: Enter SATURNINUS with AARON

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Along with me: I'll see what hole is here,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: And what he is that now is leap'd into it.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Say who art thou that lately didst descend

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Into this gaping hollow of the earth?

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: The unhappy son of old Andronicus:

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: Brought hither in a most unlucky hour,

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: To find thy brother Bassianus dead.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: My brother dead! I know thou dost but jest:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: He and his lady both are at the lodge

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Upon the north side of this pleasant chase;

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: 'Tis not an hour since I left him there.

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: We know not where you left him all alive;

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: But, out, alas! here have we found him dead.

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: Re-enter TAMORA, with Attendants; TITUS ANDRONICUS, and Lucius

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Where is my lord the king?

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Here, Tamora, though grieved with killing grief.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Where is thy brother Bassianus?

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Now to the bottom dost thou search my wound:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Poor Bassianus here lies murdered.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Then all too late I bring this fatal writ,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: The complot of this timeless tragedy;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And wonder greatly that man's face can fold

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: In pleasing smiles such murderous tyranny.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: She giveth SATURNINUS a letter

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: [Reads]  'An if we miss to meet him handsomely--

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Sweet huntsman, Bassianus 'tis we mean--

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Do thou so much as dig the grave for him:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Thou know'st our meaning. Look for thy reward

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Among the nettles at the elder-tree

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Which overshades the mouth of that same pit

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Where we decreed to bury Bassianus.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Do this, and purchase us thy lasting friends.'

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: O Tamora! was ever heard the like?

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: This is the pit, and this the elder-tree.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Look, sirs, if you can find the huntsman out

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: That should have murdered Bassianus here.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: My gracious lord, here is the bag of gold.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: [To TITUS]  Two of thy whelps, fell curs of

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: bloody kind,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Have here bereft my brother of his life.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Sirs, drag them from the pit unto the prison:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: There let them bide until we have devised

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Some never-heard-of torturing pain for them.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: What, are they in this pit? O wondrous thing!

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: How easily murder is discovered!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: High emperor, upon my feeble knee

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: I beg this boon, with tears not lightly shed,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: That this fell fault of my accursed sons,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Accursed if the fault be proved in them,--

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: If it be proved! you see it is apparent.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Who found this letter? Tamora, was it you?

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Andronicus himself did take it up.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: I did, my lord: yet let me be their bail;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: For, by my father's reverend tomb, I vow

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: They shall be ready at your highness' will

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To answer their suspicion with their lives.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Thou shalt not bail them: see thou follow me.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Some bring the murder'd body, some the murderers:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Let them not speak a word; the guilt is plain;

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: For, by my soul, were there worse end than death,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: That end upon them should be executed.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Andronicus, I will entreat the king;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Fear not thy sons; they shall do well enough.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Come, Lucius, come; stay not to talk with them.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Exeunt
